101: <p>There is a really useful extension called "<a href="http://www.xdebug.org/" rel="noreferrer">xdebug</a>" that will make your reports much nicer as well.</p>

<p>I recommend <a href="https://tracy.nette.org/en/" rel="noreferrer">Nette Tracy</a> for better visualization of errors and exceptions in PHP:</p>

<p><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/B1gSC.png" alt="Nette Tracy screenshot"></p>
<p>You might also want to try PHPStorm as your code editor.  It will find many PHP and other syntax errors right as you are typing in the editor. </p>
103:
<p>There are also component-based frameworks, such as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apache_Wicket" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Wicket</a>, that generate a lot of the HTML for you.</p>
<p>The tags that end up in the HTML are extremely basic and there is virtually no logic that gets mixed in. The result is almost empty-like HTML pages with typical HTML elements. The downside is that there are a lot of components in the <strong>Wicket</strong> API to learn and some things can be difficult to achieve under those constraints.</p>

<p>Experience has shown that JSP's have some shortcomings, one of them being hard to avoid mixing markup with actual code.</p>

<p>If you can, then consider using a specialized technology for what you need to do.  In Java EE 6 there is JSF 2.0, which provides a lot of nice features including gluing Java beans together with JSF pages through the <code>#{bean.method(argument)}</code> approach.</p>

<p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apache_Wicket" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Wicket</a> is also an alternative which completely separates Java from HTML, so a designer and programmer can work together and on different sets of code with little understanding of each other.</p>
<p>Look at Wicket.</p>

<p>You raised a good question and although you got good answers, I would suggest that you get rid of JSP. It is outdated technology which eventually will die. Use a modern approach, like template engines. You will have very clear separation of business and presentation layers, and certainly no Java code in templates, so you can generate templates directly from web presentation editing software, in most cases leveraging WYSIWYG.</p>

<p>And certainly stay away of filters and pre and post processing, otherwise you may deal with support/debugging difficulties since you always do not know where the variable gets the value.</p>

<p>In order to avoid Java code in JSP files, Java now provides tag libraries, like JSTL.</p>
<p>Also, Java has come up with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JavaServer_Faces" rel="nofollow noreferrer">JSF</a> into which you can write all programming structures in the form of tags.</p>
<p>Use JSTL tag libraries in JSP. That will work perfectly.</p>
<p>Just use the JSTL tag and EL expression.</p>

<p>Use a Backbone.js or AngularJS-like JavaScript framework for UI design
and fetch the data using a REST API. This will remove the Java dependency from the UI completely.</p>

<p>As many answers says, use JSTL or create your own custom tags. <a href="http://www.journaldev.com/2099/jsp-custom-tags-example-tutorial" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Here</a> is a good explanation about creating custom tags.</p>
104: <p>The <code>');</code> ends the query, it doesn't start a comment. Then it drops the students table and comments the rest of the query that was supposed to be executed.</p>
<p>The <code>'</code> character in SQL is used  for string constants. In this case it is used for ending the string constant and not for comment.</p>
105: <p>Both kinds of enclosed characters are strings.  One type of quote is conveniently used to enclose the other type of quote.  <code>"'"</code>  and <code>'"'</code>.   The biggest difference between the types of quotes is that enclosed identifier references are substituted for inside double quotes, but not inside single quotes.</p>
